channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Real Middle East Crisis Is Economic
item.description: The region’s economic isolation is fueling political instability and violence.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SINGH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Said to Deploy Drones After Unrest in Xinjiang
item.description: State media say drones have been used in Xinjiang against “terrorists,” a move an overseas Uighur advocacy group said represented a further militarization of a region beset by ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Uighur children playing in the streets of Kashgar, in southern Xinjiang. Xinjiang has seen growing ethnic and religious tensions in recent years.

item.title: In Liberia, a Child Thought to Have Ebola
item.description: The 10-year-old boy, found without his family, was eventually transported to a hospital in Monrovia.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: ISIS Video Purports to Show Beheading of James Foley
item.description: The terrorist group ISIS said it executed James Foley in retaliation for American airstrikes in Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: James Foley, in a photo from the website FreeJamesFoley.org, in Aleppo, Syria, in November 2012, the month he disappeared.

item.title: Open Source: Russia, Iran and Egypt Heckle U.S. About Tactics in Ferguson
item.description: Strident criticism of the action taken by the police in Ferguson, Mo., has come from authoritarian nations where the police are often venerated and dissent is scarcely tolerated.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A new advertising campaign for the Kremlin-funded news network Russia Today, or RT, tries to persuade New Yorkers to view it as an alternative to American channels.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Mining Company Lied on Spill, Official Says
item.description: Environment Secretary Juan Jose Guerra Abud said Tuesday that a mining company lied about a spill of 10 million gallons of acids and heavy metals that contaminated two rivers and a dam downstream.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: ‘Idol’ Contestant Acquitted of Aiding Terror
item.description: A former “Canadian Idol” contestant was acquitted Tuesday of conspiring to facilitate terrorism, with Superior Court Justice Charles Hackland finding insufficient evidence that he intended to join a plot.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: An Obstacle to Honoring an Archbishop Is Removed
item.description: The archbishop, a champion of the poor and critic of government repression in El Salvador, was gunned down in 1980.
item.dc:creator: By GENE PALUMBO and DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Listening Post : Obama Holds to Afghanistan Withdrawal Deadline
item.description: The president was rejecting a growing chorus of arguments in Washington that the chaos in Iraq should prompt him to reconsider his timetable for withdrawing the last soldiers from Afghanistan by the end of 2016.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: A soldier delivered mail at a base in Paktia Province, Afghanistan, that is set to close in October.

item.title: In Russia, Scenes From Ferguson Are Played as Nothing Shocking: It’s America
item.description: Events in Missouri are the latest opportunity for news media and the government to portray the United States as a hypocritical critic of speech restrictions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Rossiya 24, a government-controlled channel in Russia, is televising videos from Ferguson, Mo., like this one. Russian pro-democracy activists say the police actions are hurting their cause.

item.title: German Leader Emerges as Key Figure in Ukraine Talks
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany is emerging more and more as a pivotal leader on the Ukraine conflict as she dances delicately between opposing forces.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: As other Western states have had to focus on domestic issues, Chancellor Angela Merkel has helped ease fears in the Baltics.

item.title: Pieve Santo Stefano Journal: In Italy, the City of Diaries Honors Personal Memories
item.description: Having collected more than 7,000 personal memoirs, Italy’s Pieve Santo Stefano has become known as the City of Diaries.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalia Cangi, the director of the National Diary Archive Foundation. More than 7,000 memoirs line the archive’s shelves.

item.title: Rockets From Gaza and Israeli Response Break Cease-Fire
item.description: Three rockets fired from Gaza struck southern Israel, breaking a cease-fire, drawing Israeli retaliation and prompting Israel to recall its delegation from talks aimed at ending the latest conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Smoke rose from what witnesses said was an Israeli air strike in Gaza City on Tuesday after three rockets fired from Gaza struck southern Israel.

item.title: Plenty of Room at the Top of Ukraine’s Fading Rebellion
item.description: In what separatist officials call the “Ukrainianization” of the leadership, almost all the original Russian leaders of the rebellion have resigned and gone home, replaced by Ukrainians of dubious qualifications.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fyodor D. Berezin is a novelist who has risen quickly through the rebel ranks in Ukraine.

item.title: Saudi Prince Is Identified as Target of Paris Heist
item.description: While French police have refused to release his identify, the French news media reported that it was Prince Abdul Aziz, 41, who was ambushed by gunmen in a Hollywood-style robbery.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Who Will Stand Up for the Christians?
item.description: People are getting killed because of their beliefs. Jews have a duty to speak up.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RONALD S. LAUDER

item.title: Court Orders Release of Hunger-Striking Indian Activist
item.description: Irom Sharmila began refusing to eat almost 14 years ago to protest a law that gives impunity to armed forces serving in the insurgency-racked state of Manipur.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Next Leader May Echo Maliki, but Iraqis Hope for New Results
item.description: During the American occupation, Haider al-Abadi, a Shiite chosen to be Iraq’s next prime minister, resisted the idea of reconciliation with Sunnis, but some hope he can break the mold of recent leaders and govern in an inclusive way.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: In Retaking of Iraqi Dam, Evidence of American Impact
item.description: The scene around the strategically important Mosul Dam bore testament to the deadly effect American airstrikes were having on the militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, or ISIS.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga at the Mosul Dam the morning after they and Iraqi forces defeated militants of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Relief Official Urges Groups to Step Up Ebola Efforts
item.description: Dr. Joanne Liu, the president of Doctors Without Borders, called the outbreak in West Africa a “complete disaster” of a scale not yet known.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. and SHERI FINK

item.title: Pakistanis Protest in Capital, Seeking Prime Minister’s Resignation
item.description: Thousands of opposition supporters headed toward a fortified zone in Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad, to press for the prime minister’s resignation.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Opposition supporters marched toward the center of Islamabad on Tuesday night to demand the resignation of the Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Flights Yield Candid Conversations
item.description: Talking to reporters on his way home from South Korea, the pope touched on military intervention in Iraq, the beatification of an assassinated archbishop, and his own neuroses.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis spoke with reporters on Monday as he flew back to Italy from South Korea.

item.title: Ukrainian and Russian Leaders Will Meet as Rebels Continue to Falter
item.description: The government said it saw a chance for peace in eastern Ukraine after word that the two leaders and European Union officials would meet next week.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Ukrainians approach the border crossing at Donetsk on Tuesday.

item.title: Afghan Officials Interrogate a Times Correspondent
item.description: The Afghan Attorney General’s Office later banned the correspondent, Matthew Rosenberg, from leaving the country over objections to his reporting.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York Times correspondent Matthew Rosenberg on Tuesday after being banned from leaving the country by the Afghan attorney general’s office.

item.title: Ebola Death Toll in West Africa Tops 1,200
item.description: The latest figures from the World Health Organization showed that more than 80 people died of the illness between Aug. 14 and 16.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: United Nations health workers in New Kru Town, Liberia. Residents are being urged to wash their hands to help prevent the spread of the epidemic.
